comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: In 1910 there was a B. L. Jefferson listed as the register of the State Board of Land Commissioners in Colorado;  there was also a B. L. Jefferson listed in the Colorado State Medical Society directory for 1900.   In 1913, B. L. Jefferson of Colorado was appointed by President Wilson as "minister to a Latin-American country."

comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: This from the State Department: Jefferson, Benjamin Lafayette (1871-1950) Non-career appointee 1913 Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary, Nicaragua ( ref. www.state.gov/r/pa/ho/po/11552.htm) However this does not confirm it is the same B. L. Jefferson. Consider this from the New York Times of June 14, 1913: "... June 13 - President Wilson to-day made the following nominations: ... Minister to Nicaragua, Benjamin L. Jefferson of Colorado. ... Mr. Jefferson lives at Steamboat Springs, Col., is a physician, is now Register of the Colorado Lands Board, and was for several years State Senator. He and the President are friends. ... " Looks like he's the man.

comment.author: 35277872@N05
comment._content: Thanks for the information.  A similar unscanned portrait by Harris and Ewing at the Library of Congress copyrighted in 1913 confirms this is Benjamin Lafayette Jefferson, probably taken around the same time. The date "7/11/13" in the upper left corner of this photo may indicate that the Bain News Service distributed the photo in relation to Jefferson's Nicaraguan appointment. We can add the information to the description when we update it.
